introduction.html.title: Introduction
introduction.html.body:
Introduction
This document describes how to install Mind Studio, troubleshoot faults during the installation, and upgrade Mind Studio online.

Mind Studio is an AI full-stack development platform developed based on Huawei-developed NPUs. It provides web services such as chip-based operator development, debugging, optimization, and third-party operator development. Mind Studio also supports network migration, optimization, and analysis at the network layer and a set of visualized AI engine-based drag-and-drop programming services at the service engine layer, which greatly lowers the AI engine development threshold.
The device development kit （DDK） is a NPU-based digital developer suite. The DDK can be used to build a compilation environment for projects. Different release packages integrate DDKs of different NPU forms. The DDK of the current version contains the dependency libraries and header files of components such as the TE, DVPP, and process orchestration. Users can compile the project files by using  makefile.

about-third-party-content.html.title: About Third-Party Content
about-third-party-content.html.body:
About Third-Party Content

This document may contain third-party content, such as third-party information, products, services, software, components, and data. Huawei does not control or assume any responsibility for third-party content, including but not limited to the accuracy, compatibility, reliability, availability, legitimacy, appropriateness, performance, non-infringement, and update status, unless otherwise specified in this document. Any third-party content mentioned or cited in this document does not represent Huawei's recognition or guarantee of the third-party content.
If a user requires a third-party license, the user must obtain a third-party license through legal means, unless otherwise specified in this document.

about-third-party-tools.html.title: About Third-Party Tools
about-third-party-tools.html.body:
About Third-Party Tools
After Mind Studio is installed, the gdb and gcc tools are retained on the server.

Reason for retention: The programming tools are provided for users to develop applications. The gdb and gcc tools need to be reserved so that users can compile and debug applications after opening them.
Application scenario: Users utilize the programming tools to develop applications, use gcc to compile programs, and use gdb to debug programs. The tools are used only in the development environment instead of the production environment.
Risk: Attackers may use the existing debugging and compilation tools to compile new programs, causing secondary attacks on the system. It is recommended that these tools be used only in the development environment.

about-personal-data.html.title: About Personal Data
about-personal-data.html.body:
About Personal Data
Personal Data

Usage Scenario

When logging in to Mind Studio, the user needs to enter the user name and password. The IP address of the host is collected.
The data set imported by the user is used when the model is used for performing inference. The data set may contain personal privacy data.


Collected Items

IP address, user name, password, and data set


Collection Source and Method

User names and passwords are collected during user registration, IP addresses are collected during login and logout, and data sets are uploaded by users.


Purpose and Security Protection Measure

User names and passwords are used as credentials for user login authentication. IP addresses are used to identify the client for user operations during audit, and data sets are used by users to perform inference on data. In addition, when you use Mind Studio, the server where Mind Studio is installed records your latest account login and operation logs. The operation logs include the IP address and user name for security audit.Data is transmitted under HTTPS-based encryption.User names and passwords are encrypted using PBKDF2WithHmacSHA256 and stored on the local Mind Studio server. IP addresses are recorded in logs in plain text. Log files are controlled by the permission (600) and data sets are controlled by the permission (600).


Data Retention Period and Policy

The system forcibly changes the user name and password every three months by default.The log data collected by Mind Studio is recorded on the host where Mind Studio is deployed. Therefore, the log can be manually deleted and cleared by the user. The maximum size of an operation log file is 20 MB. If the maximum size is exceeded, a new operation log file is generated. The maximum number of operation log files is 30. If the maximum number is exceeded, the generated operation log files overwrite the earliest operation log files.Due to repeated inference, data sets are retained on the Mind Studio server during inference.


Clearance Method

Users can delete personal data (such as the user names, passwords, IP addresses, and imported data sets) by uninstalling Mind Studio or on the GUI.Users can delete personal data by using profiling on the GUI.Due to repeated inference, data sets are stored in the ~/HIAI_DATANDMODELSET/workspace_mind_studio directory of the server on the host during inference and need to be cleared by users.



Data Export Method (Interfaces or Commands) and Implementation Scheme (Anonymization or Pseudonymization)

N/A


Data Export Instructions

N/A

preparing-the-server-environment.html.title: Preparing the Server Environment
preparing-the-server-environment.html.body:
Preparing the Server Environment
The server serves as the installation environment of Mind Studio. The following requirements on the hardware and operating system （OS） must be met.
Table  1  Ubuntu system version information

Category

Version Restriction

Obtaining Method

Precautions



Hardware

≥ 4 GB memory is recommended for a single-user scenario.

-

If the memory size of the Linux host is 4 GB, the size of the model file should be less than or equal to 350 MB for model conversion and simulation on Mind Studio. Otherwise, the OS may be unstable.If the configurations of the Linux host are upgraded, for example, the memory is expanded to 8 GB, the supported operation specifications should be increased proportionally.For example, if the memory is expanded from 4 GB to 8 GB, the size threshold of the model file should be 700 MB.



OS

16.04.3

Download the required version from http://old-releases.ubuntu.com/releases/16.04.3/. You can download the desktop version ubuntu-XXX-desktop-amd64.iso or server version ubuntu-XXX-server-amd64.iso.
 NOTE: In ubuntu-XXX-desktop-amd64.iso and ubuntu-XXX-server-amd64.iso, XXX indicates the version number.


Ensure that the OS supports the UTF-8 character set. Otherwise, you cannot view the support documents by using online help of Mind Studio after the installation. For details about the troubleshooting solution, see What Do I Do If I Cannot View the Online Help Documents?.During model conversion, if a custom TE plug-in is loaded, the GUI may be stuck. Run the uname -r or cat /proc/version command to check whether the Linux kernel version is earlier than 4.18. If so, upgrade the Linux kernel by referring to:https://bugzilla.kernel.org/attachment.cgi?id=277305



Python

2.7

For details, see Installing Dependent Packages.

-


JDK

1.8.0_171+

For details, see Installing Dependent Packages.

-

setting-a-common-user.html.title: Setting a Common User
setting-a-common-user.html.body:
Setting a Common User
Context

The tool can be installed and used only in a single-user scenario.
The tool can be installed by a common user only. The  root user is not supported in installation. 

Procedure
If no common user exists, create one as the  root user as follows:

Run the following command to create a common user and set the home directory of the common user.
#useradd -d /home/username  -m  username

Run the following command to set the password: 
#passwd  username

Run the following command to access the /home  directory:
chmod 750  /home/username



 NOTE:The  umask value of a common user cannot be greater than  0027.

setting-the-source.html.title: Setting the Source
setting-the-source.html.body:
Setting the Source
Configure the source of Ubuntu 16.04. The official source address is in the  /etc/apt/sources.list  file. Run the  sudo apt-get update  command to check whether the source is available. If the dependencies cannot be downloaded according to the source, you are advised to configure an available proxy or search for available sources.

installing-dependent-packages.html.title: Installing Dependent Packages
installing-dependent-packages.html.body:
Installing Dependent Packages
Prerequisites

If the common user has the sudo permission, begin installation directly.
If the common user does not have the sudo permission, perform the configuration as follows.

Run the following commands to open the  /etc/sudoers  file:
su root
chmod u+w /etc/sudoers
vi /etc/sudoers

Add the following content to the  # User privilege specification  file:
username  ALL=（ALL:ALL） NOPASSWD:SETENV:/usr/bin/apt-get
username  indicates the name of the common user who executes the installation script.

Run  :wq!  to save the file.

Run the following command to remove the write permission on the  /etc/sudoers  file:
chmod u-w /etc/sudoers

 NOTE:Ensure that the last line of the /etc/sudoers file is #includedir /etc/sudoers.d. If the information does not exist, add it manually.  





Procedure
Switch to the common user and perform the following operations:

Run the following command to install the dependency （You are advised to copy the following commands to Word or Notepad and copy them to the server for execution） :
sudo apt-get install gcc g++ cmake curl libboost-all-dev libatlas-base-dev unzip haveged python-skimage python3-skimage python-pip python3-pip liblmdb-dev libhdf5-serial-dev libsnappy-dev libleveldb-dev make graphviz autoconf libxml2-dev libxml2 libzip-dev libssl-dev sqlite3 python

During the python-skimage installation, software python, python-cycler, python-decorator, python-matplotlib, python-numpy, python-pil, python-pyparsing, python-dateutil, python-tz, and python-six will be introduced. The software will be checked later.

If a message is displayed indicating that the python-skimage software is not installed, run the following command to install the software:
sudo apt-get install xxx

 NOTE:Replace  xxx with the software introduced during the python-skimage installation.   


If most of the python-skimage software is missing, run the following commands:
sudo apt-get remove python-skimage
sudo apt-get install python-skimage



During the python3-skimage installation, software python3, python3-cycler, python3-decorator, python3-matplotlib, python3-numpy, python3-pil, python3-pyparsing, python3-dateutil, python3-tz, and python3-six will be introduced. The software will be checked later.

If a message is displayed indicating that the python-skimage software is not installed, run the following command to install the software:
sudo apt-get install xxx

 NOTE:Replace  xxx with the software introduced during the python3-skimage installation.   


If most of the python-skimage software is missing, run the following commands:
sudo apt-get remove python3-skimage
sudo apt-get install python3-skimage





 NOTE:Run  make graphviz autoconf libxml2-dev libxml2 libzip-dev libssl-dev sqlite3 python  to install the dependency required for the installation of profiling.  


Install the JDK.

Run the  sudo apt-get install -y openjdk-8-jdk  command.

 NOTE:   

If the JDK is installed on the local host, run the  java -version  command to check the version number. If the version number is earlier than 1.8.0_171, uninstall the JDK, download the sources again by referring to section  3.1.2, and reinstall the JDK.  
If the JDK is installed by using the source described in  Setting the Source  and the commands described in  2.a, run the  java -version  command to check the version number. If the version number is earlier than 1.8.0_171, run the  sudo apt-get update  command to update the source.  
If the source version is still earlier than 1.8.0_171 after performing either of the preceding step, download the  jce_policy-8.zip  file from the  Oracle official website  and replace the  local_policy.jar and  US_export_policy.jar files in the package to their counterparts in  %JAVA_HOME%\jre\lib\security  （%JAVA_HOME%  is an environment variable, which can be viewed in the .bashrc file）.  



Set the environment variable.
The installation and running of Mind Studio depend on the  JAVA_HOME  environment variable. If the environment variable is not set, the Mind Studio installation script exits the installation. Set  JAVA_HOME  as follows:

Run the  vi ~/.bashrc  command in any directory to open the  .bashrc  file.
Add the following content to the end of the file:
export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64 
export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH

 NOTE:JAVA_HOME  indicates the JDK installation directory. If the JDK has been set, change it as required. If the JDK is installed according to the preceding steps, you do not need to change the installation directory.  


Run the  :wq!  command, save the file, and exit.

Run the  source ~/.bashrc  command for the environment variable to take effect:
Run the  echo $JAVA_HOME  command to check the environment variable setting. The following information is displayed:
/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64

Run the  which jconsole  command to check the JDK installation.
If the following information is displayed, the installation is successful. Otherwise, the JDK installation fails.
/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/bin/jconsole

client.html.title: Client
client.html.body:
Client
The client accesses the Mind Studio environment using a browser.

 NOTE:64-bit Chrome of version 67.0.3396.87 or later is required.

software-package-preparation.html.title: Software Package Preparation
software-package-preparation.html.body:
Software Package Preparation
Before installing the tool, prepare the following software packages:

Obtain the software packages from  ascenddk-private  in  https://github.com/Ascend.

Table 1  describes the software packages.
Table  1  Overview of the software packages

Installation Package

Content

Integrity Verification File for the Software Package

Application Scenario



mini_mind_studio_developerkit-x.x.x.x.rar

Mind-Studio_Ubuntu-x86-64.tarMSpore_DDK-x86_64.ubuntu16.04-aarch64.ubuntu16.04-aarch64.ubuntu16.04.tar.gzinstall.shcheck_sha.shadd_sudo.shdel_sudo.shprofiling_sudo.sh

mini_mind_studio_developerkit-x.x.x.x.rar.asc

Installation package on Ubuntu, for developer board scenarios






 NOTE:   

x  indicates the version number of the software package.  
Mind-Studio_Ubuntu-x86-64.tar  is the Mind Studio installation package. A DDK is distinguished by  ddk  in its file name.  install.sh  is used for installation, and  check_sha.sh  is used to verify the integrity of the preceding three files. （check_sha.sh  is automatically called to perform integrity check during the execution of  install.sh.）, the  add_sudo.sh  script is used to add rights to common users, and the  del_sudo.sh  script is used to delete common user rights.

mind-studio-installation.html.title: Mind Studio Installation
mind-studio-installation.html.body:
Mind Studio Installation
This section describes the procedure for installing Mind Studio and some common operations.

 NOTICE:   

Currently, only one set of Mind Studio can be installed on a host. If Mind Studio already exists in the system, you need to uninstall it by referring to  Uninstalling Mind Studio  as the installation user.  
After uninstalling Mind Studio, clear the /tmp and  /dev/shm directories. Then, reinstall Mind Studio.  



Verification of the Software Package IntegrityBefore installing the software package, check whether the software package is incomplete or damaged due to network or storage device faults.
InstallationThere are two installation modes: automatic installation （boot installation） and manual installation. After successful installation, you need to check whether the current version is the required one.
Common OperationsIf the server is restarted, you need to restart Mind Studio as well. You can also run commands to stop the services related to Mind Studio. Before upgrading the tool to a new version, uninstall the earlier version.

verification-of-the-software-package-int.title: Verification of the Software Package Integrity
verification-of-the-software-package-int.body:
Verification of the Software Package Integrity 
Before installing the software package, check whether the software package is incomplete or damaged due to network or storage device faults.
Upload the obtained files  mini_mind_studio_*.rar  and  mini_mind_studio_*.rar.asc  to the Linux home directory of the common user where Mind Studio is to be installed.

Configure the opengpg public key. For details, see  Configuring the openpgp Public Key.
Run the following command as the Mind Studio installation user to check whether the software package is valid and integrate, as shown in  Figure 1.
gpg --verify "mini_mind_studio\*.rar.asc_"
Figure  1  Verifying the software package integrity

In the returned information,  27A74824  indicates the public key ID.
If the message  Good signature  is displayed without  WARNING or  FAIL, the signature is valid and the integrity verification is passed.
If  WARNING or  FAIL is displayed, the verification fails. Rectify the fault by referring to the handling suggestions described in  What Do I Do If a WARNING or FAIL Result Is Returned in the Integrity Verification of a Software Package?.




 NOTE:   

The integrity verification can be performed only when the software package and the .asc file are stored in the same path.

installation.html.title: Installation
installation.html.body:
Installation
There are two installation modes: automatic installation （boot installation） and manual installation. After successful installation, you need to check whether the current version is the required one.
If the installation is performed by a common user, the permission may be insufficient. During the installation, you need to check the following information:
Chek whether the common user has the read, write, and execute permissions on the directory （for example,  director） where the  mini_mind_studio_*.rar  file is stored.
If the common user does not have the permission, run the  su root  command to switch to the  root user and run the following commands:
chown  username:usergroup  director
chmod 750 director

 NOTE:   

username  indicates the name of the common user who installs Mind Studio.  
usergroup indicates the group to which the common user belongs.  
If the tool is installed in a different path, ensure that the path has the 750 permission.  



Boot InstallationBoot installation guides the user in setting parameters and installing Mind Studio and DDK. You are advised to use this installation mode preferentially.
Manual InstallationIn this mode, you need to manually install Mind Studio and the DDK respectively.
Verifying the Installation

boot-installation.html.title: Boot Installation
boot-installation.html.body:
Boot Installation
Boot installation guides the user in setting parameters and installing Mind Studio and DDK. You are advised to use this installation mode preferentially.
Procedure

Decompress the installation package.
Upload the file  mini_mind_studio_*.rar  obtained as described in  Software Package Preparation  to the home directory of the Linux common user where Mind Studio is to be installed.
Run the  unzip mini_mind_studio_*.rar  command to decompress the package.

Run the installation script  ./install.sh  or  bash install.sh.

Follow the instructions to perform the settings.

If the common user who installs Mind Studio does not have the  sudo  permission, the following message is displayed and the installation exists.
Please check if add_sudo.sh, del_sudo.sh exists and execute the add_sudo.sh script with root privileges
This message indicates that the common user does not have the permission to perform the installation. You need to switch to the  root user to add the permission:
su root
./add_sudo.sh  username
Then, switch to the common user and run the  ./install.sh  command again.

 NOTE:If the installation fails, re-add the permission as the  root user.  


If the common user who installs Mind Studio has the sudo permission, the following information is displayed:
Successfully add permission!

Specify whether to install the Linux kernel patch.
[INFO] Please make sure that the Linux Kernel Version is higher than 4.18 or apply this patch https://bugzilla.kernel.org/attachment.cgi?id=277305 when Linux Kernel Version below 4.18, otherwise maybe stuck when converting model using omg with TE plugin. Continue? [Y/N]: （Enter  Y or  y and press  Enter  to reject the installation of the Linux kernel patch, or enter  N or  n  and press  Enter  to install the Linux kernel patch before installing Mind Studio.）

Specify whether to use the default settings for installation.
[INFO] Installation will run automatically with DEFAULT config, [Y/N]: （Enter  Y or  y and press  Enter. The default settings will be used for installation. Otherwise, you need to set the parameters yourself.）

Configure the IP address used for starting Mind Studio. Either of the following situations may occur.
[INFO] Your ip address is xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx

[INFO] Press ENTER to continue or input a NEW ip address: （The IP address of the eth0 Ethernet adapter is obtained. Press  Enter  to continue or enter a custom IP address）
[INFO] Get ip address fail, please input your ip address: （The IP address of the eth0 Ethernet adapter is not obtained. Enter a custom IP address.）


Select the backup path for saving data when the Mind Studio is uninstalled.
[INFO] Please input backup path: （default is /home/username/wsbackup）: （Input a backup path or press  Enter to use the default setting.）

Specify whether to load data from the backup path. The following information is displayed only when the default path is selected in Step  3.f  and  /home/username/wsbackup  is not empty:
[INFO] Do you want to load data from /home/username/wsbackup ?  [Y/N]: （Enter Y  or  y  and press  Enter to load data from  /home/username/wsbackup, or enter N  or  n and press  Enter to reject the loading.）

Set the Mind Studio listening port. In Step  3.e, if  Y or y  is entered and  Enter  is pressed to use the default configuration, this step is skipped.
[INFO] Please input you port （default is 8888）: （Input a port number or press  Enter to use the default setting.）

Set tool_path for saving tools during Mind Studio is running. In Step  3.e, if  Y or y  is entered and  Enter  is pressed to use the default configuration, this step is skipped.
[INFO] Please input tool path （default is /home/username/tools）: （Input a tool path or press  Enter to use the default setting.）


Set profiler_port （Profiling listening port）. In Step  3.e, if  Y or y  is entered and  Enter  is pressed to use the default configuration, this step is skipped.

[INFO] Please input you profiler port （default is 8099）: （Input a port number or press  Enter to use the default setting.）

Set apache_user （user name of the Apache service running on the background of Profiling）.  In Step  3.e, if  Y or y  is entered and  Enter  is pressed to use the default configuration, this step is skipped.
[INFO] Please input you apache_user （default is msvpUser）: （Input the Apache user name or press  Enter to use the default configuration.）

Specify whether to back up the  tools  installation directory. （If the installation directory is not empty, this message is displayed.）
[INFO] /home/username/tools is not empty.  Files in the directory will be cleared during installation.  Are you sure to back up them?[Y/N]: （Enter Y  or  y  and press  Enter  to exit the installation. Back up the installation directory, and then run the /.install.sh script to perform the installation again. Enter  N  or  n and press  Enter to delete the contents in  /home/username/tools  and continue to install Mind Studio.）

Check whether the local Python software needs to be replaced with a specified version.
pip: numpy=1.14.3 decorator=4.0.10 Pillow=5.2.0 gevent=1.3.6 easydict=1.9 pyyaml=3.13
pip3: numpy=1.14.3 decorator=4.0.10 Pillow=5.2.0 matplotlib=2.1.0
[INFO] The following python packages need to be replaced, whether to overwrite the installation?[Y/N]: （Enter Y  or  y  and press  Enter  to confirm the version replacement and continue the installation, or enter N  or  n and press  Enter  to reject the version replacement and exit the installation.）

 NOTE:   

The common user must have the permission to create the tool path and backup path.  
For details about parameters such as the IP address, port number, tool path, and backup path, see  2.  





Install Mind Studio and the DDK.
Mind Studio is installed in the  tools directory where the install.sh script is stored.
If the installation fails, see  FAQs.

 NOTE:After the installation is complete, the  del_sudo.sh script is automatically executed to revoke the permission of the common user, no matter the installation succeeds or fails.

manual-installation.html.title: Manual Installation
manual-installation.html.body:
Manual Installation
In this mode, you need to manually install Mind Studio and the DDK respectively.

Decompress the installation package.
Decompress the  mini_mind_studio_*.rar  package to obtain the Mind Studio installation package  Mind-Studio_Ubuntu-x86-64.tar.
Upload the file  Mind-Studio_Ubuntu-x86-64.tar  to the home directory on Linux of the common user where Mind Studio is to be installed.
Run the  tar -xvf Mind-Studio_Ubuntu-x86-64.tar  command to decompress the package.

Configure the configuration file.
Go to the  scripts directory that is generated after decompression and find the parameter configuration file  env.conf.
The configuration file contains the following parameters:  ip,  port,  toolpath,  backup,  profiler_port,  install_user,  use_eth0, and  package_path. They are described as follows:

ip: IP address used for starting Mind Studio

 NOTE:This parameter must be set during installation.If ip  is set to  any, the IP address of the network adapter is automatically obtained during startup.  


port: listening port of Mind Studio

toolpath: path of required tools during the execution, for example, database path  db.
backup: path of the backup files of  project,  my-model, and  my-datasets.
profiler_port: listening port of Profiling 

 NOTE:   

Ensure that the port is not in use. You can run the  netstat  -anp | grep  portnumber  command to view the port number. Some ports cannot be customized in the Chrome browser （for example, ports 6666, 6000, and 6667）. You are advised to set this parameter to a value greater than 7000.  
Ensure that these ports are not occupied: port 4412 for exec, 4411 for terminal, 4403 for wsagent_debug, 4401 for wsagent, 3002 for hiai-agent, 3001 for cce_profiler, 3003 for hiai_log, and profiler_port.  



max_log_size: maximum number of log files that can be set by users in the  ~/tools/log/hiai_agent_log  folder. The default value is  10. Considering the impact of disk space, you are not advised to set this parameter to a large value.

apache_user: user name of the Apache service on the Profiling server
install_user: current installation user

 NOTE:This parameter must be set during installation.The common user must have the permission to create the tool path and backup path.  


package_path: path of the permission addition script  add_sudo.sh. It must be an absolute path, for example, /home/username

 NOTE:This parameter must be set during manual installation. Otherwise, the profiling installation will fail.  


use_eth0: whether to use eth0 for startup by default when  ip  is set to  any

 NOTE:During the installation, the default value of  use_eth0 is  true. That is, when  ip  is set to  any, eth0 is used for startup by default. If  use_eth0 is set to  false, you can select one from the IP addresses of multiple network adapters before startup.  


load_date: whether to load data from the backup path. The default value is  true, indicating that backup data is loaded from the backup path. If this parameter is set to  false, the backup data is not loaded.



Run the installation script.
The  scripts directory contains the  mind_studio.sh  file, which is the installation script. Perform  2  before running the script.

Run the following command to install Mind Studio and the DDK in a common scenario:
bash mind_studio.sh install {absolute_ddk_path}

Run the following command to install Mind Studio separately when Mind Studio fails to be properly installed.
bash mind_studio.sh install

Run the following command to install the DDK separately. If the DDK is not properly installed, you need to restart the Mind Studio after re-installing the DDK.
bash mind_studio.sh installDDK {absolute_ddk_path}



 NOTE:{absolute_ddk_path}  is the absolute path of the DDK package, for example,  /home/username/ddk.tar.gz.  


Specify whether to back up the  tools  installation directory. （If the installation directory is not empty, this message is displayed.）
[INFO] /home/username/tools is not empty. Files in the directory will be cleared during installation. Are you sure to back up them?  [Y/N]: （Enter  Y or  y  and press Enter to exit the installation. Back up the contents in  /home/username/tools  and then run the script again. Enter  N or  n to delete the contents in  /home/username/tools  and continue the installation.）

verifying-the-installation.html.title: Verifying the Installation
verifying-the-installation.html.body:
Verifying the Installation
Installation process
The following processes are executed during the installation of Mind Studio:

Installing the MongoDB database
Installing the DDK
Installing the performance analyzer, HiAI CCE Profiler 
Starting the Mind Studio service
Checking whether backup data （in the  backup directory） needs to be imported
Installing the Apache service and PHP, and starting the Apache service

Now, Mind Studio is ready for development.
Verifying the Installation

Use the Chrome browser to access the following website to check whether the Mind Studio GUI can be accessed. If yes, Mind Studio has been installed successfully. Otherwise, the installation fails.
https://IP:Port

Use the Chrome browser to access the following website to check whether the Profiling GUI can be accessed. If yes, the Profiling tool has been installed successfully. Otherwise, the installation fails.
https://IP:Profiler_port



 NOTE:   

Replace  IP with the IP address of the server where Mind Studio is installed.  Port  of Mind Studio is default to  8888.  Profiler_port  of Profiling is default to  8099. If the installation IP address of Mind Studio, Mind Studio port number, and Profiling port number are mapped, enter the mapped IP address and port numbers. You can modify them in the  ~/tools/scripts/env.conf  file.  
~/tools  is  the default  toolpath  setting, which can be customized during Mind Studio installation. You can view the value of  toolpath in the  scripts/env.conf  file.  
You can run the  find / -name 'env.conf'  command to view the location of the  env.conf  file in the  script directory.  


The default user name for logging in to Mind Studio is  MindStudioAdmin, which cannot be changed. The initial password is  Huawei123@. For details, see chapter 2 "User Management" in the  Mind Studio Basic Operations.  
The user name for logging in to Profiling is  msvpadmin, and the initial password is  Admin12#$. You can create a common user by referring to section 3.2.3 "Viewing the Performance Analysis" in the   Mind Studio Auxiliary Tools.  
Check whether the installed version is correct. For details, see  Querying the Mind Studio Version.  
If the installation fails, view the log in ~/tools/log/mind_log  and rectify the fault according to the error information.  
After Mind Studio is installed, you are advised to change the default password of the MongoDB user for security considerations. For details, see  Changing the User Password.  


Version Description

You need to set the following two paths for the installation of Mind Studio.

toolpath: Stores the data set and model zoo.
backup: Stores the backup data of the project directory when Mind Studio is uninstalled.


Created projects are stored in the  /projects  directory. This directory cannot be changed.

common-operations.html.title: Common Operations
common-operations.html.body:
Common Operations
If the server is restarted, you need to restart Mind Studio as well. You can also run commands to stop the services related to Mind Studio. Before upgrading the tool to a new version, uninstall the earlier version.

Starting Mind Studio  

Stopping Mind Studio  

Uninstalling Mind Studio  

Querying the Mind Studio Version  

Configuring the openpgp Public Key  

Changing the User Password  

Changing the IP addresses

starting-mind-studio.html.title: Starting Mind Studio
starting-mind-studio.html.body:
Starting Mind Studio
To start Mind Studio, run the  bash start.sh  command in the  ~/tools/bin  directory on Linux.
The following services are triggered as well:

MongoDB service, whose process can be viewed by running the command  ps -ef | grep mongod
HiAI_CCE-Profiler performance analyzer service, whose process can be viewed by running the commands  ps -ef|grep httpd  and  ps -ef|grep redis
Mind Studio service, whose process can be viewed by running the command  ps -ef | grep java | grep -v 'grep' | grep HiAI-Studio-.*/tomcat/bin/bootstrap.jar

Use the Chrome browser to access the following website to check whether the Mind Studio GUI can be accessed. If yes, Mind Studio has been installed successfully. Otherwise, the installation fails.
https://IP:Port

 NOTE:Replace  IP with the IP address of the server where Mind Studio is installed.  Port of Mind Studio is default to  8888. If the installation IP address of Mind Studio and Mind Studio port number are mapped, enter the mapped IP address and port number. You can modify them in the ~/tools/scripts/env.conf  file.

stopping-mind-studio.html.title: Stopping Mind Studio
stopping-mind-studio.html.body:
Stopping Mind Studio
To stop Mind Studio, run the following command in the  ~/tools/bin  directory on Linux:
bash stop.sh
The following services are stopped as well:

MongoDB service
HiAI_CCE-Profiler performance analyzer service
Mind Studio service


 NOTE:After Mind Studio is stopped, the Mind Studio GUI cannot be accessed through Chrome.

uninstalling-mind-studio.html.title: Uninstalling Mind Studio
uninstalling-mind-studio.html.body:
Uninstalling Mind Studio
Log in to Mind Studio as the installation user and run the  ./uninstall.sh  command in the ~/tools/bin  directory on Linux to uninstall the Mind Studio.
During the uninstallation, perform the following operations:

If the common user who uninstalls Mind Studio does not have the  sudo  permission, the following message is displayed and the uninstallation exists.
Please check if add_sudo.sh, del_sudo.sh exists and execute the add_sudo.sh script with root privileges
This message indicates that the common user does not have the permission to perform the installation. You need to switch to the  root user to add the permission:
su root
./add_sudo.sh  username
Then, switch to the common user and run the  ./uninstall.sh  command again.

 NOTE:If the uninstallation fails, add the permission as the  root user.  


If the common user who uninstalls Mind Studio has the  sudo permission, the following information is displayed:
Successfully add permission!

Specify whether to back up the user data.
[WARNING] Do you need to backup for user data （include projects my-datasets my-model caffe-model mongodb profiling） ?  [Y/N]
Enter  Y or  y  and press  Enter to back up the user data and  3.a, or enter  N or  n  and press  Enter to skip the backup and enter  3.b.）

If user data is backed up, the following message is displayed:
[WARNING] Directory /home/username/wsbackup is not empty, please make your choice! [Y:（Continue to overwrite backup）/N:（Change a directory）]:
Enter  Y  or y and press  Enter to overwrite the backup, or enter N  or  n  and press  Enter to change the backup path.

If the user data is not backed up, the system prompts whether to delete the user data.
[WARNING] Are you sure to remove user data （include projects my-datasets my-model caffe-model mongodb profiling） ? [Y/N]:
Enter  Y  or y and press  Enter to delete the user data or enter N  or  n  and press  Enter to retain the user data.



Uninstall MongoDB.

Stop the HiAI_CCE-Profiler service.
Stop the web service.
Back up user data to the  backup directory, including  project,  my-model, and  my-datasets.


 NOTE:After the uninstallation, if you want to decompress the installation package again or decompress the installation package of a later version, delete the  del_sudo.sh and  profiling_sudo.sh scripts from the original package, switch to the root user, and run the following commands:su rootchattr -i del_sudo.sh profiling_sudo.shrm -rf del_sudo.sh profiling_sudo.sh

querying-the-mind-studio-version.html.title: Querying the Mind Studio Version
querying-the-mind-studio-version.html.body:
Querying the Mind Studio Version
You can query the version by running a command in the background or using the GUI.

Query the version by running a command in the background 
After Mind Studio is installed, go to the  ~/tools/conf  directory and run the  cat version  command to view the Mind Studio version, as shown in  Figure 1.
Figure  1  Querying the Mind Studio version in the background

Query the version on the GUI
Log in to Mind Studio and choose  Help > About. The Mind Studio version information is displayed, as shown in  Figure 2.
Figure  2  Querying the Mind Studio version in the foreground



 NOTE:The time information shown in  Figure 1  and  Figure 2  is for reference only.

configuring-the-openpgp-public-key.html.title: Configuring the openpgp Public Key
configuring-the-openpgp-public-key.html.body:
Configuring the openpgp Public Key
Prerequisites

Configure the public key as the installation user of Mind Studio.
The GnuPG tool has been installed on Linux.
Verification:

If the GnuPG tool has been installed, run the  gpg --version  command in the shell and the following information is displayed:


If the GnuPG tool is not installed, install the tool by following the instructions provided in  http://www.gnupg.org/, the official website of GnuPG.




Configuring the Public Key

Obtain the public key file.
Go to the  OpenPGP download page  and click the download link, as shown in  Figure 1. The file download page is displayed.
Figure  1  Click to download the file.
The  KEYS  file is the public key file, as shown in  Figure 2.
Figure  2  Selecting the KEYS file

 NOTE:If you want to switch to the English interface, click    in the upper right corner.  


Upload the downloaded  KEYS.txt  file to the Linux OS where Mind Studio is located,
for example,  /home/username/openpgp/keys.

Import the public key file.
Run the following command to go to the directory that contains the public key file  KEYS.
# gpg --import "/home/username/openpgp/keys/KEYS.txt"
Figure  3  Import the public key file.

 NOTE:/home/username/openpgp/keys  indicates the absolute path of the public key file  KEYS. Replace  username  with the name of the Mind Studio installation user.  


Run the following command to view the import result:
# gpg --fingerprint
Figure  4  Checking the import result

Verify the public key.

The validity of the OpenPGP public key must be verified based on the public key ID, fingerprint, UID, and the publisher of the public key. The published information of the OpenPGP public key is as follows:

Public key ID: 27A74824
Key fingerprint: B100 0AC3 8C41 525A 19BD C087 99AD 81DF 27A74824
UID: OpenPGP signature key for Huawei software （created on 30th Dec,2013）support@huawei.com

After the information is verified, you can set the trust level for the public key

Set the trust level for the public key by running the following command:
# gpg --edit-key "OpenPGP signature key for Huawei" trust
Information similar to the following is displayed. Enter  5  after  Your decision?, which indicates  I trust ultimately. Enter  y  after  Do you really want to set this key to ultimate trust? （y/N）.
Figure  5  Setting the trust level for the public key



Run the  quit  command to exit.

changing-the-user-password.html.title: Changing the User Password
changing-the-user-password.html.body:
Changing the User Password
Changing the Password of a Common OS User
The method for changing the password of a common OS user （except the  root user） is the same. This topic takes the Mind Studio installation user as an instance （for example, the  ascend user）.

Log in to the OS as a common user （for example,  ascend, the Mind Studio installation user）.
Run the  passwd username  command to change the user password.
For example:
#  passwd ascend
The following information is displayed:
Changing password for ascend. 
New Password:

Enter the new password as prompted and press  Enter. The following information is displayed:
Reenter New Password:

Input the new password again as prompted and press  Enter.
The password is successfully changed if the following command output is displayed:
Password changed.

Perform the following operations to check whether the new password takes effect.

Exit the OS.
Use the new password to log in to the OS.
If the login is successful, the new password has taken effect.




Changing the Password of the root User 

Log in to the OS as a common user （for example,  ascend, the Mind Studio installation user）.
Run the following command to switch to user  root:
su - root

Run the following command to change the password of the root user:
passwd
Enter the login password of the common user, the new password of the root user, and the new password of the root user as prompted. Then, press  Enter. The password is changed successfully.
Enter new UNIX password:
Retype new UNIX password:


Changing the Password of the MongoDB User 

Make sure that a Mind Studio project is started.
Run the  java -version  command in the Linux CLI to check whether the JDK has been installed and JDK environment variable has been configured.
Figure  1  Checking whether the JDK has been installed and JDK environment variable has been configured

 NOTE:If the JDK is not installed or the JDK environment variable is not configured, an error is reported when the MongoDB password is changed, and the modification fails.  


Log in to the Mind Studio server as the Mind Studio installation user, go to the  tools/scripts  directory, and run the  mongoPwdUpdate.sh  script to change the MongoDB password
by running the following command:
sh mongoPwdUpdate.sh
Enter the password according to the system output.
Please enter your admin user old password:
Please enter your admin user new password:
Please enter your admin user new password again:
Please enter your minddbuser user new password:
Please enter your minddbuser user new password again:

 NOTE:   

A password must contain at least eight characters, including letters, digits, and special characters （excluding @ % and spaces）.  
If the password is successfully changed, the following message is displayed:  update mongodb pwd success!!!!  
If the password is changed for the first time, the default password of the  admin user is  abJ!19bj.  
~/tools  is the default  toolpath  setting, which can be customized during Mind Studio installation. You can view the value of  toolpath in the  scripts/env.conf  file. You can run the  find / -name 'env.conf'  command to view the location of the  env.conf  file in the  script directory.  



Refresh the Mind Studio project and check whether the functions are normal.
Figure  2  Refreshing the Mind Studio project


Updating the Key for Encrypting Character Strings
Context
After Mind Studio is installed, a key for encrypting character strings is provided by default. The key is managed in a two-layer structure, including the root key and working key. In scenarios such as changing the password of the MongoDB user and changing the password of the Mind Studio certificate key store, the system uses the working key to encrypt the character strings. You are advised to update the key periodically （for example, every 90 days）.
You can log in to the Mind Studio server as the Mind Studio installation user, view the working key  work_key.json  in  ~/mongo/config/keygen, and view the root key in  ~/mongo/config/keygen/rootkey.
Procedure

Log in to the Mind Studio server as the Mind Studio installation user and go to the  ~/tools/bin  directory.
Run the following command to update the key:
./updateMongoKey.sh
After the command is executed, the system stops the Mind Studio （including Profiling）, updates the key, and restarts the Mind Studio （including Profiling）. After the key is updated, a new root key and a new working key are generated in the  ~/mongo/config/keygen  directory, and the files there before the key update are backed up.

The backup file  crt.conf_bak of the crt.conf  file is generated in  ~/tools/scripts.
The backup file  profiler.cfg_bak  of the  profiler.cfg  file is generated in  ~/tools/conf.
The backup file  redis.cfg_bak  of the  redis.cfg  file is generated in  ~/tools/conf.
The backup directory  config_bak of the  config directory is generated in  ~/mongo.
The backup file workkey.img_bak  of the  workkey.img file is generated in  ~/tools/vendor.

If an exception occurs during key update, all operations are rolled back, that is, the status before the key update is returned. If the rollback fails, you need to manually restore the  *_bak  backup files and folder and restart Mind Studio. Run the following command to restart the Mind Studio in the  ~/tools/bin  directory:
bash stop.sh
bash start.sh

 NOTE:~/tools  is the default  toolpath  setting, which can be customized during Mind Studio installation. You can view the value of  toolpath in the  scripts/env.conf  file. You can run the  find / -name 'env.conf'  command to view the location of the  env.conf  file in the  script directory.

changing-the-ip-addresses.html.title: Changing the IP addresses
changing-the-ip-addresses.html.body:
Changing the IP addresses
If you want to change the IP address of the Ubuntu server, the IP address used for Mind Studio installation needs to be changed as well.

If the IP address in the  env.conf  file is the IP address of the Ubuntu server, change it to the new IP address of the Ubuntu server.
If the IP address in the  env.conf file is set to  any:
If  use_eth0 in the  env.conf  file is set to  true, change the IP address of eth0 and restart Mind Studio for the new IP address to take effect.
If  use_eth0 in the  env.conf  file is set to  false, restart Mind Studio and select one from the IP addresses of multiple network adapters for the new IP address to take effect.




 NOTE:The path of the  env.conf file is as follows:  ~/tools/scripts/env.conf

version-upgrade.html.title: Version Upgrade
version-upgrade.html.body:
Version Upgrade
Online upgrade of Mind Studio and Atlas 200 DK developer board is supported. You do not need to uninstall Mind Studio and reinstall it. You can directly upgrade the tool and the Atlas 200 DK developer board.

Preparing for the Upgrade  

Performing Upgrade  

Exception Handling

preparing-for-the-upgrade.html.title: Preparing for the Upgrade
preparing-for-the-upgrade.html.body:
Preparing for the Upgrade

Ensure that the haveged dependency has been installed on the server where Mind Studio is installed. Otherwise, run the  sudo apt-get install haveged  command on the server. Before the upgrade, you need to run the  add_sudo.sh  script as the  root user to add the  sudo permission. For details, see  3.
Before the upgrade, obtain the following installation packages. For details about how to obtain the packages, see  Software Package Preparation.
Table  1  Overview of the software packages

Installation Package

Integrity Verification File for the Software Package

Application Scenario



mini_mind_studio_*.rar

mini_mind_studio_*.rar.asc

Ubuntu OS


mini_developerkit-x.x.x.x.rar

mini_developerkit-x.x.x.x.rar.asc

Installation package for the Atlas 200 DK developer board





Place the installation packages and verification files in the same directory.

 NOTE:   

x  indicates the version number of the software package.  
If only Mind Studio needs to be upgraded, you do not need to download the Atlas 200 DK installation package. If you need to upgrade the Atlas 200 DK, the corresponding Mind Studio installation package is required, for example,  mini_mind_studio_developerkit.rar.  
To verify software package integrity, install the GnuPG tool on the Linux server where Mind Studio is installed and configure the openpgp public key.  For details, see 5.3.5 "Configuring the openpgp Public Key" in the  Mind Studio Installation Guide

performing-upgrade.html.title: Performing Upgrade
performing-upgrade.html.body:
Performing Upgrade

 NOTICE:Perform the upgrade as the Mind Studio installation user. Before the upgrade, switch to the  root user and run the  add_sudo.sh script to add the  sudo permission to the Mind Studio installation user. For details, see  3.a.  


Choose  Help > Upgrade. The  Upgrade dialog box is displayed, as shown in  Figure 1.
Figure  1  Upgrade dialog box
You can upgrade Mind Studio and Atlas 200 DK developer board separately or at the same time. If you click  , the corresponding module is hidden or displayed.  Table 1  describes the parameters on the  Upgrade page.
Table  1  Parameters on the upgrade page

Parameter

Description



Mind Studio Path

Stores the Mind Studio installation package.


Studio Asc Path

Stores the verification file of the Mind Studio installation package.


Mini Package Path

Stores the installation package of the Atlas 200 DK developer board.


Mini Asc Path

Stores the verification file of the installation package of the Atlas 200 DK developer board.


Board IP

Indicates the IP address of the Atlas 200 DK developer board.






 NOTE:If the Atlas 200 DK developer board is upgraded independently, Mind Studio does not stop.  


Click    next to  Mind Studio Path,  Studio Asc Path,  Mini Package Path, and  Mini Asc Path, select the upgrade packages and .asc files with the same name as the upgrade packages, respectively, enter the IP address of the developer board in the  Board IP  text box, and click  update  to upload the files, as shown in  Figure 2.
Figure  2  Uploading the upgrade packages and verification files

 NOTE:The package names displayed in the  Mind Studio Path  and  Mini Package Path  text boxes are examples only.  


After successful upload and verification, the dialog box as shown in  Figure 3  is displayed. Click  OK  and the upgrade window is displayed. During the upgrade of Mind Studio and the developer board, as shown in  Figure 4, the back-end services are disconnected and the front end is masked. Do not refresh or close the window during this phase. During the upgrade of the developer board only, the back-end services of Mind Studio are not be disconnected and the upgrade progress is displayed, as shown in  Figure 5.
Figure  3  Message displayed after the package is uploaded and verified
Figure  4  Upgrading
Figure  5  Developer board upgrade progress


After the upgrade is successful, Mind Studio is restarted. The Mind Studio login page is displayed, as shown in  Figure 6.
Figure  6  Upgrade Success dialog box

 NOTE:After the upgrade is successful or the upgrade is canceled, close the dialog box shown in  Figure 2. The redundant folders （upgrade and  upgradeForLog） generated due to the upgrade by the Mind Studio background server will be automatically deleted.

exception-handling.html.title: Exception Handling
exception-handling.html.body:
Exception Handling
If an exception occurs during the upgrade, an error message is displayed in the upgrade dialog box. You can view the exception information in the  ~/upgradeLogForMindStudio  directory. The following log files are provided for the upgrade process.
Table  1  Upgrade log files

Log File

Description



stopMindStudio.log

Records information about stopping Mind Studio, generated when Mind Studio and Atlas 200 DK developer board are upgraded separately.


upgradeMindStudio.log

Records information about uninstalling Mind Studio of an earlier version, saving user data, installing Mind Studio of a later version, restoring user data, and installing the DDK.


upgradeMini.log

Records information about the process of transferring packages to the Atlas 200 DK developer board and restarting the Atlas 200 DK developer board.


startMindStudio.log

Records information about starting Mind Studio, generated when Mind Studio and Atlas 200 DK developer board are upgraded separately.






If the error information  Unpacking package failed  is displayed during the upgrade, check whether the  upgradeassembly  folder exists in the  /tmp  directory. If yes, delete the folder and try again.
If only  stopMindStudio.log  exists during the upgrade, check the log content, rectify the fault, restart Mind Studio, and perform the upgrade again.
If only  upgradeMindStudio.log  exists but startMindStudio.log  does not, run the  bash mind_studio.sh rollback  command in the  ~/upgrade/scripts  directory to perform rollback. After the rollback is complete, restart the system and perform the upgrade again.

If only startMindStudio.log  exists, restart Mind Studio in the installation directory to complete the upgrade.

During the upgrade of the Atlas 200 DK developer board, a script is executed. The return value of the script is displayed on the page when an error occurs.

The return value  0  indicates that the script is executed successfully.
The return value  1  indicates that the SD card space on the Atlas 200 DK developer board is insufficient. 
The return value  2  indicates that the script fails to be decompressed. 
Other return values are not defined currently.


 NOTE:Ensure that the IP address can be restored after the Atlas 200 DK developer board is restarted. If the IP address cannot be restored, manually configure the IP address. The upgrade log information of the Atlas 200 DK developer board is stored in  upgradeMini.log  in the  ~/upgradeLogForMindStudio  directory.

faqs.html.title: FAQs
faqs.html.body:
FAQs

What Do I Do If a Source Configuration Error Occurs When the apt-get update Command Is Run During Mind Studio installation?  

What Do I Do If "Software cycler （for python） decorator （for python） xxx error" Is Displayed During the Installation?  

What Do I Do If an Error Is Reported During the Installation of Mind Studio?  

What Do I Do If Mind Studio Cannot Start Normally?  

What Do I Do If Mind Studio Fails to Be Installed?  

What Do I Do If the MongoDB Service Fails to Be Stopped During the Uninstallation?  

What Do I Do If Mind Studio Does Not Support Automatically Running at Server Startup?  

What Do I Do If Profiling Fails to Be Installed?  

What Do I Do If a WARNING or FAIL Result Is Returned in the Integrity Verification of a Software Package?  

What Do I Do If I Cannot View the Online Help Documents?

what-do-i-do-if-a-source-configuration-e.title: What Do I Do If a Source Configuration Error Occurs When the apt-get update Command Is Run During Mind Studio installation?
what-do-i-do-if-a-source-configuration-e.body:
What Do I Do If a Source Configuration Error Occurs When the apt-get update Command Is Run During Mind Studio installation?
Symptom

1:
In the environment preparation phase before Mind Studio deployment, after the source dependency is configured and the apt-get update command is executed, the following error message is displayed:
Aborted (core dumped) 
Reading package lists... Done
E: Problem executing scripts APT::Update::Post-Invoke-Success 'if /usr/bin/test -w /var/cache/app-info -a -e /usr/bin/appstreamcli; then appstreamcli refresh > /dev/null; fi'
E: Sub-process returned an error code

2:
In the environment preparation phase before Mind Studio deployment, after the source dependency is configured and the apt-get update command is executed, the following error message is displayed:
E: Could not get lock /var/lib/dpkg/lock - open (11: Resource temporarily unavailable) 
E: Unable to lock the administration directory (/var/lib/dpkg/), is another process using it?


Solution

1:
Run the following command to install the libappstream3 library:
sudo apt-get purge libappstream3

2:
Run the following commands to delete lock:
sudo rm /var/cache/apt/archives/lock
sudo rm /var/lib/dpkg/lock

what-do-i-do-if-software-cycler-（for-pyt.title: What Do I Do If "Software cycler （for python） decorator （for python） xxx error" Is Displayed During the Installation?
what-do-i-do-if-software-cycler-（for-pyt.body:
What Do I Do If "Software cycler （for python） decorator （for python） xxx error" Is Displayed During the Installation?
Symptom 1
The following error information is displayed during the installation:
Software cycler(for python) decorator(for python) xxx error (xxx indicates the dependent software package.)
Solution 1

 NOTE:Before running the following commands, ensure that the server where the Mind Studio is installed can connect to the external network.  


Run the  dpkg -l | grep python-xxx  command to check whether the software is installed. If the following information is displayed, the software is installed. Otherwise, run the  sudo apt-get install python-xxx command to install it.


If the software is installed, run the  python -c "import  xxx"  command to check whether the software is usable. If the software is usable, run the installation script again to install Mind Studio. If the problem persists, go to Step  3.

 NOTE:To check Pillow, replace  xxx _with  PIL. To check dateutil, replace  xxx with  datetime. To check other software, replace  xxx_  with the software name.  


If the software has been installed but the  python -c "import  xxx"  check fails, run the  sudo apt-get remove python-xxx command to uninstall the software, and then run the  sudo apt-get install python-xxx  command to reinstall it.

If the problem persists after  3, run the following commands:
sudo apt-get remove python-xxx
sudo apt-get remove python-skimage
sudo apt-get remove python
sudo apt-get autoremove
sudo apt-get install python-skimage


Symptom 2
The following error information is displayed during the installation:
Software cycler(for python3) decorator(for python3) xxx error (xxx indicates the dependent software package.)
Solution 2

Run the  dpkg -l | grep python3-xxx  command to check whether the software is installed. If the following information is displayed, the software is installed. Otherwise, run the  sudo apt-get install python3-xxx command to install it.


If the software is installed, run the  python3 -c "import  xxx"  command to check whether the software is usable. If the software is usable, run the installation script again to install Mind Studio. If the problem persists, go to Step  3.

 NOTE:To check Pillow, replace  xxx _with  PIL. To check dateutil, replace  xxx with  datetime. To check other software, replace  xxx_  with the software name.  


If the software has been installed but the  python3 -c "import  xxx"  check fails, run the  sudo apt-get remove python3-xxx command to uninstall the software, and then run the  sudo apt-get install python3-xxx  command to reinstall it.

If the problem persists after  3, run the following commands:
sudo apt-get remove python3-xxx
sudo apt-get remove python3-skimage
sudo apt-get remove python3
sudo apt-get autoremove
sudo apt-get install python3-skimage

what-do-i-do-if-an-error-is-reported-dur.title: What Do I Do If an Error Is Reported During the Installation of Mind Studio?
what-do-i-do-if-an-error-is-reported-dur.body:
What Do I Do If an Error Is Reported During the Installation of Mind Studio?
The following error information does not affect the installation process and can be ignored.
Figure  1  Installation error information
Figure  2  Boot Installation

what-do-i-do-if-mind-studio-cannot-start.title: What Do I Do If Mind Studio Cannot Start Normally?
what-do-i-do-if-mind-studio-cannot-start.body:
What Do I Do If Mind Studio Cannot Start Normally?
The possible causes are as follows:

The MongoDB service fails to be started.
Symptom:  The MongoDB process is not found after the following command is run:
ps -ef | grep mongod
Solution: Go to the directory  vendor/mongodb/mongodb-linux-x86_64-3.0.6/bin  and run the following command:
./mongod --fork --dbpath /data/db --rest --syslog

MongoDB fails to be started.
Symptom: The following error message is displayed when MongoDB is started
ERROR:child process failed, exited with error number 100
Solution: The possible cause is that exceptions occur when MongoDB is started or stopped last time. As a result, the MongoDB database is locked.
Log in to the background server as the Mind Studio installation user and check whether the  mongod.lock file exists in the ~/tools/db  directory, which indicates a database deadlock. In this case, delete the file and reinstall MongoDB. If the problem persists, delete the whole database folder and reinstall MongoDB.

what-do-i-do-if-mind-studio-fails-to-be-.title: What Do I Do If Mind Studio Fails to Be Installed?
what-do-i-do-if-mind-studio-fails-to-be-.body:
What Do I Do If Mind Studio Fails to Be Installed?
If Mind Studio fails to be installed, you are advised to uninstall Mind Studio. Make sure that the uninstallation is successful before you reinstall Mind Studio, to avoid the affects of unthorough uninstallation.
For details, see  Uninstalling Mind Studio.

what-do-i-do-if-the-mongodb-service-fail.title: What Do I Do If the MongoDB Service Fails to Be Stopped During the Uninstallation?
what-do-i-do-if-the-mongodb-service-fail.body:
What Do I Do If the MongoDB Service Fails to Be Stopped During the Uninstallation?
Symptom: During the uninstallation, the MongoDB service fails to be stopped due to abnormal operations （for example, manually deleting database files）, as shown in  Figure 1.
Figure  1  MongoDB service stop failure during the uninstallation
Solution:  You can run the  kill  or  pkill  command on Linux to forcibly stop MongoDB. Then, uninstall MongoDB.

what-do-i-do-if-mind-studio-does-not-sup.title: What Do I Do If Mind Studio Does Not Support Automatically Running at Server Startup?
what-do-i-do-if-mind-studio-does-not-sup.body:
What Do I Do If Mind Studio Does Not Support Automatically Running at Server Startup? 
Mind Studio does not support automatic running at server startup. To manually enable the function, perform the following steps:

Go to the  /home/username/tools/bin  directory on Linux where Mind Studio is installed.
Figure  1  Directory for storing the scripts of Mind Studio

Run the  bash start.sh  command.
Figure  2  Running the bash start.sh command
If the preceding information is displayed, it indicates that automatic running at server startup has been enabled for Mind Studio.

what-do-i-do-if-profiling-fails-to-be-in.title: What Do I Do If Profiling Fails to Be Installed?
what-do-i-do-if-profiling-fails-to-be-in.body:
What Do I Do If Profiling Fails to Be Installed?
Installation as a Common User
If the profiling fails to be installed, view the logs in  ~/tools/log/profilerlogs/profiling.log. The possible causes are as follows:

Symptom: Restart httpd service ... Failed!  is found in the log. The HTTPd service fails to be started.
Verification:
Run the  ps -aux|grep httpd  command. If no process exists, the HTTPd service fails to be started.
Solution:

Check whether the installation directory specified by the common user has the 750 permission.
If not, run the  chmod 750 [Installation directory]  command to modify the permission.

If the permission of the installation directory is correct, check whether the $JAVA_HOME  configuration of the common user is correct.
Verification:
Run the  echo $JAVA_HOME  command. If the variable is null, manually configure it.
For details about how to configure the environment variable  JAVA_HOME, see  2.


After the configurations in  1.a  and  1.b  are complete, uninstall Profiling and reinstall it.

Symptom:  Either of the following information is displayed when the installation command is executed:
1. gcc package is need to be installed... failed!
2. Installation error, please check if libxml2-dev libxml2 libzip-dev are installed!
Solution:
Install the dependency packages first, such as sshpass, expect, gcc, g++, make, graphviz, autoconf, libxml2-dev, libxml2, libzip-dev, and libssl-dev. Ensure that the required software packages exist in the configured Ubuntu apt source.

what-do-i-do-if-a-warning-or-fail-result.title: What Do I Do If a WARNING or FAIL Result Is Returned in the Integrity Verification of a Software Package?
what-do-i-do-if-a-warning-or-fail-result.body:
What Do I Do If a WARNING or FAIL Result Is Returned in the Integrity Verification of a Software Package?
If a WARNING or FAIL result is returned in the integrity verification of a software package, the verification fails. Rectify the fault by referring to the handling suggestions described in  Table 1.
Table  1  Verification result examples

Verification Result Description

Displayed Information

Verification Result

Handling Suggestion



The signature verification is successful without exception.

gpg: Signature made Thu Jan 9 15:29:06 2014 CST using RSA key ID 27A74824
gpg: Good signature from "OpenPGP signature key for Huawei software (created on 30th Dec,2013) "

PASS

N/A


The signature verification fails.

gpg: Signature made Thu Jan 9 15:29:06 2014 CST using RSA key ID 27A74824
gpg: BAD signature from "OpenPGP signature key for Huawei software (created on 30th Dec,2013) "

FAIL

Download the target file again.


The public key cannot be found.

gpg: Signature made Thu Jan 9 15:20:01 2014 CST using RSA key ID 27A74824
gpg: Can't check signature: public key not found

FAIL

Download the public key again. For details, see section 5.3.5 Configuring the openpgp Public Key.


The signature verification is successful, but the public key is not ultimately trusted.

gpg: Signature made Thu Jan 9 15:29:06 2014 CST using RSA key ID 27A74824
gpg: Good signature from "OpenPGP signature key for Huawei software (created on 30th Dec,2013) "
gpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature!
gpg: There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner.
Primary key fingerprint: B100 0AC3 8C41 525A 19BD C087 99AD 81DF 27A7 4824

WARNING

After confirming that KeyID is 27A74824, set the Huawei public key to ultimate trust. For details, see 5.3.5 "Configuring the openpgp Public Key."


The corresponding source file cannot be found.

gpg: no signed data
gpg: can't hash datafile: No data

FAIL

Download the target file again.


The signature has expired.

gpg: Signature made 04/24/13 10:50:29 CST using RSA key ID 133B64E5
gpg: Expired signature from " OpenPGP signature test key "
gpg: Signature expired 04/25/13 10:50:29 CST

FAIL

Download an updated target file.


The signature verification is successful, but the public key has been revoked.

gpg: Signature made 06/13/13 11:14:49 CST using RSA key ID 133B64E5
gpg: Good signature from " OpenPGP signature test key "
gpg: WARNING: This key has been revoked by its owner!
gpg: This could mean that the signature is forged.
gpg: reason for revocation: Key is no longer used
gpg: revocation comment:

WARNING

Download the latest public key and an updated target file.


The corresponding signature file cannot be found in the source file.

None

WARNING

Download the signature file corresponding to the target file.

what-do-i-do-if-i-cannot-view-the-online.title: What Do I Do If I Cannot View the Online Help Documents?
what-do-i-do-if-i-cannot-view-the-online.body:
What Do I Do If I Cannot View the Online Help Documents?
Problem description:  After installing Mind Studio on the Linux server, choose  Help > Documents  as shown in  Figure 1. The online help page is displayed. The content cannot be refreshed after a directory is clicked.
Figure  1  Navigation path for online help
Solution: Run the  locale  command to check whether the Linux server supports the UTF-8 character set, as shown in  Figure 2. The following solutions are provided for the two situations.
Figure  2  Viewing the character set

If the Linux server does not support the UTF-8 character set:
To install the UTF-8 character set, perform the following steps:

Run the  vi  command to open the  /etc/default/locale  file and change the content to the following:
LANG="en_US.UTF-8"
LANGUAGE="en_US.UTF-8:"
Run the  :wq!  command to save the file and exit.

Run the following command:
locale-gen -en_US:en
If an error is reported after this command is executed, go to Step 3 directly.

Run the following command to restart the server:
reboot



If the Linux server does not support the UTF-8 character set:
In the directory where the online help documents are located, for example,  ~tools/Mind-Studio-5.22.0/tomcat/webapps, run the following command:
convmv -f gb2312 -t UTF-8 --nosmart --notest -r docs

open-source-third-party-libraries.html.title: Open Source Third-Party Libraries
open-source-third-party-libraries.html.body:
Open Source Third-Party Libraries
cereal
cereal is a header-only BSD-licensed C++11 serialization library. It is designed to be fast, light-weight, and easy to extend. cereal takes arbitrary data types and reversibly turns them into different representations, such as compact binary encodings, XML, or JSON. 
For details, visit the cereal official website: http://uscilab.github.io/cereal/
GFlags
Google GFlags, the Global Flags Editor, contains a Python-friendly C++ library that implements command-line flags processing, replacing systems like getopt（）.
For details, visit the GFlags official website: https://github.com/gflags/gflags
glog
Google glog is a library that implements application-level logging. This library provides logging APIs based on C++-style streams and various helper macros. Similar to assert defined in the standard C library, only it provides more output information and flexibility.
For details, visit the glog official website: https://github.com/google/glog
OpenCV
OpenCV （short for Open Source Computer Vision Library） is a library of programming functions mainly aimed at real-time computer vision. The cross-platform library sets its focus on real-time image processing, computer vision, and pattern recognition programs.
For details, visit the OpenCV official website: https://opencv.org/
Protobuf
Protobuf （short for Protocol buffers） are Google's language-neutral, platform-neutral, extensible mechanism for serializing structured data. It is useful in developing programs to communicate with each other over a wire or for storing data. The version currently used is 3.5.1.
For details, visit the official website: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/
Caffe
Caffe is short for Convolutional Architecture for Fast Feature Embedding. Is a commonly used deep learning framework in video and image processing applications. The version currently used is 1.0.
For details, visit the official website: http://caffe.berkeleyvision.org/
TensorFlow
TensorFlow is an open source software library for numerical computation using data flow graphs. The version currently used is 1.8.
For details, visit the official website: https://www.tensorflow.org/
